Abstract 28 Recent studies showed that sulfidated nano zerovalent iron (S-nZVI) is a better 29 alternative to non-sulfidated nano zerovalent iron (NS-nZVI) commonly used for 30 contaminated site remediation. However, its reactivity with different halogenated 31 pollutants such as tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) remains unclear. In this study, we 32 explored the reductive transformation of TBBPA by S-nZVI and compared it with that 33 by NS-nZVI. The results showed that over 90% of the initial TBBPA (20 mg L-1) was 34 transformed by S-nZVI within 24 h of reaction, which was 1.65 times as high as that 35 for NS-nZVI. The TBBPA transformation by S-nZVI was well described by a 36 pseudo-first-order kinetic model, whilst that by NS-nZVI was well fitted by a 37 three-parameter single exponential decay model. After 11 weeks of aging, S-nZVI 38 was still able to transform up to 56% of the initial TBBPA within 24 h of reaction; by 39 contrast, the two-week aged NS-nZVI lost more than 95% of its original capacity to 40 transform TBBPA. Moreover, S-nZVI showed only an approximately 20% decrease in 41 its capacity to transform TBBPA in the seventh cycle, while NS-nZVI was no longer 42 able to transform TBBPA in the fourth cycle. XPS analysis suggested the formation of 43 FeS layer on S-nZVI surface and electrochemical analysis revealed an elevated 44 electron transfer capacity of S-nZVI, which were likely responsible for the superior 45 performances of S-nZVI in TBBPA transformation. While the transformation rate of 46 TBBPA by S-nZVI decreased with increasing initial concentration of TBBPA, it 47 showed an increasing trend with increasing S/Fe ratio and initial concentration of 48 S-nZVI. The study indicated that S-nZVI has the potential to be a promising 49 alternative to NS-nZVI for remediation of TBBPA-contaminated aquatic 50 environments. 51 Keywords: TBBPA; S-nZVI; Sulfidation; Transformation pattern; Reusability; Aging 52

Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) is the most abundantly applied brominated flame 55 retardant (BFR) with an annually worldwide demand over 170, 000 tons in 2004 56 (Covaci et al., 2009). Approximately 90% of TBBPA is used in printed circuit boards 57 as a reactive BFR and the remaining 10% is used in plastic polymers as an additive 58 BFR (Alaee et al., 2003). The widespread use of TBBPA and its incomplete removal 59 from waste printed circuit boards and plastic waste during waste treatment have 60 already led to the large-scale release of TBBPA into the environment. ecent reports 61 documented that the levels of TBBPA in leachates from industrial landfills were up to 62 620 ng L-1 (Osako et al., 2004), whereas those of TBBPA in effluents from sewage 63 treatment works could be as high as 85 ng L-1 (Morris et al., 2004). Despite its 64 hydrophobic nature, TBBPA can be transported and accumulated in aquatic 65 environments. Indeed, residues of TBBPA have been widely detected in a variety of 66 water, sediment and aquatic organism samples (e.g., Morris et al., 2004; Harrad et al., 67 2009; He et al., 2013). Remarkably, a maximum concentration up to 9.75 mg kg-1 was 68 found for the TBBPA residues in river sediments from England (Morris et al., 2004). 69 TBBPA is known as a thyroid hormone agonist as well as an estrogen (Kitamura et al., 70 2002; Decherf et al., 2010). It was thought to cause lethal effects on aquatic organisms 71 like fish and algae even at low concentrations (Darnerud, 2003). Therefore, it is of 72 great importance to develop effective methods to remove TBBPA from contaminated 73 aquatic environments. 74 In the last decade, nanoscale zerovalent iron (nZVI) has been recognized as a 75 promising option for dealing with soils, groundwater and sediments contaminated by 76 chlorinated organic compounds due to its high reactivity and low cost (O’Carroll et al., 77 2013; Mukherjee et al., 2016). More recently, there has been evidence that nZVI also 78

has the potential to remediate TBBPA-contaminated environmental matrices (Lin et 79 al., 2012). Note, however, that iron can react with water and cause precipitation of 80 iron oxide or hydroxide on the surface of nZVI, which can dramatically reduce the 81 reactivity of nZVI and thereby its efficiency in contaminant (e.g., TBBPA) removal 82 (Guan et al., 2015). Several types of strategies have been devised to improve the 83 reactivity of nZVI to target contaminants (such as TBBPA). Firstly, nZVI-based 84 bimetals (e.g., Fe/Pd and Fe/Ni) were synthesized and demonstrated in the lab to have 85 a greater reactivity towards TBBPA compared to nZVI (Huang et al., 2013; Li et al., 86 2016a). Secondly, the combination of either nZVI or nZVI-based bimetals with 87 physical approaches (e.g., ultrasound assistance and microwave radiation) was found 88 to be able to enhance the transformation rate of TBBPA (Luo et al., 2010, 2011). 89 Thirdly, the addition of bentonite has proven to be a useful option for accelerating the 90 transformation of TBBPA by nZVI (Yan et al., 2013). Unfortunately, these alternative 91 strategies also seem to suffer from some inherent limitations: (1) the short lifetime of 92 nZVI-based bimetals and the potential toxicity of noble metals released from these 93 bimetals are of considerable concern (Guan et al., 2015), (2) physical approaches are 94 generally hard to implement in the field for reasons related to the high energy costs 95 (Ince et al., 2001; Remya and Lin, 2011), and (3) the synergistic effects of bentonite 96 and nZVI would be weak if the bentonite was not closely contacted with nZVI (Guan 97 et al., 2015). 98 Recently, the potential roles of sulfidated nanoscale zerovalent iron (S-nZVI) in 99 remediation of sites contaminated by chlorinated organic compounds, has gained 100 increasing attention, because there is evidence that it can assist in maximizing the 101 benefits of nZVI-based approaches and helping to overcome their limitations. First of 102 all, S-nZVI was found to have a higher reactivity towards certain contaminants than 103

non-sulfidated nanoscale zerovalent iron (NS-nZVI). For example, Rajajayavel and 104 Ghoshal (2015) reported that the degradation rate constant of trichloroethylene (TCE) 105 by S-nZVI was approximately 40 times greater than that of NS-nZVI. Similar results 106 were also observed by Kim et al. (2011, 2013). Secondly, the reactivity of S-nZVI 107 with contaminants tends to be more stable than that of NS-nZVI. As demonstrated by 108 Kim et al. (2013), the effects of groundwater solutes on TCE removal capacity of 109 S-nZVI were less pronounced than their effects on that of nZVI. Thirdly, unlike other 110 nZVI-based materials that are synthesized through a series of complex procedures, 111 S-nZVI can be produced simply via a single-step synthesis (Kim et al., 2011; 112 Rajajayavel and Ghoshal, 2015). Indeed, S-nZVI may occur naturally in the 113 environment through microbially-assisted sulfidation of NS-nZVI (Rickard, 1995; 114 Watson et al., 2000). Fourthly, sulfidation is expected to reduce the toxicity of 115 NS-nZVI as little toxicity was observed for other sulfidated nanoparticles (Reinsch et 116 al., 2012; Levard et al., 2013). Lastly, such a readily available material is 117 cost-effective compared to other nZVI-based bimetals consisting noble metals. It is 118 therefore interesting to explore the potential use of S-nZVI as an attractive candidate 119 for remediation of sites contaminated by brominated organic compounds (e.g., 120 TBBPA). However, little laboratory research has been done to address such an 121 intriguing topic. 122 In this study, the performance of S-nZVI in mediating TBBPA transformation 123 was investigated for the first time and compared with that of NS-nZVI under a set of 124 uniform conditions. The comparison was focused on not only the transformation 125 patterns (including rate, dynamic, transformation product and pathway) but also the 126 longevity and reusability as these factors are very important for the potential use of 127 nZVI-based nanoparticles in remediation of TBBPA contamination. Further, the 128

Unlike the 130 previous studies in which a water/cosolvent mixture containing 50% of cosolvent (v/v) 131 was used to prepare reaction solutions for TBBPA transformation by nZVI-based 132 materials (e.g., Huang et al., 2013; Li et al., 2016a), here a water/cosolvent mixture 133 with only 2% of cosolvent was used as the reaction solution in order to decrease the 134 effect of cosolvent on TBBPA transformation. Therefore, the results of this study can 135 help not only improving our understanding of the reactivity of S-nZVI with TBBPA 136 and but also developing S-nZVI-based remedial options that may be applicable to 137 various aquatic environments contaminated by TBBPA. 138

Results and discussion 296 3.1 Overall performances of S-nZVI and NS-nZVI in TBBPA transformation 297 As shown in Fig. 1, after 24 h of reaction, 91% of the initial TBBPA (20 mg L-1) was 298 transformed by S-nZVI, compared favorably to a 55% reduction by NS-nZVI, 299 indicating a 36% increase in the capacity for TBBPA transformation by S-nZVI. 300 Such an elevated capacity could be attributed to the formation of an FeS layer on the 301 nZVI surface. The XPS analysis showed S2-, S2 2- and Fe(II)-S were present on the 302 surface of S-nZVI (Table 1, Text S1 and Fig. S2), suggesting that iron sulfides (i.e., 303

By contrast, S 2-, S2 2- and 304 Fe(II)-S were not detected on the NS-nZVI surface; instead, iron oxide and hydroxide 305 (i.e., Fe3O4 and FeO(OH); Table 1, Text S1 and Fig. S2) were main species found on 306 NS-nZVI. Meanwhile, Table 1 and Fig. S2 showed that Fe(0) was present on the 307 surface of NS-nZVI, but not on S-nZVI. It is intuitive that the formation of FeS on 308 nZVI surface may have enhanced the efficiency of electron conduction between nZVI 309 and the contaminants due to the excellent electrical conductivity of iron sulfides (Kim 310 et al., 2011; Rajajayavel and Ghoshal, 2015). This hypothesis was supported strongly 311 by our electrochemical analysis as S-nZVI had a higher electron transfer capacity than 312 NS-nZVI. As shown in the CV cycle profiles (Fig. 2A), the redox peaks of 313 S-nZVI-modified GCE had a higher current density but a smaller pear-to-peak 314 separation (0.346 V vs 0.401 V) as compared to those of NS-nZVI-modified GCE, 315 indicating a better electrochemical reversibility of S-nZVI (Zheng et al., 2009). 316 Furthermore, the typical Nyquist plots (Fig. 2B) showed that the S-nZVI-modified 317 GCE had a smaller semicircle diameter but lower Z" values at high frequency than the 318 NS-nZVI-modified GCE, suggested that S-nZVI had a greater overall rate of electron 319 transfer than NS-nZVI (Turcio-Ortega et al., 2012). The observed elevated capacity of 320 TBBPA transformation by S-nZVI was also likely because iron sulfide surface on 321 S-nZVI had greater hydrophobicity than iron oxide surface of NS-nZVI as more 322 hydrophobic binding sites favor stronger interactions with hydrophobic TBBPA 323 (Vaughan and Ridout, 1971; Kim et al., 2011). Moreover, the elevated transformation 324 capacity by S-nZVI could also have resulted from its lowered aggregation tendency 325 due to deposition of FeS on nZVI surface (Su et al., 2015), which was consistent with 326 greater BET SSA of S-nZVI than NS-nZVI (Table S1). It is likely that BPA may be 339 eventually formed in the NS-nZVI system if the reaction lasted for longer time 340 periods as indicated in Lin et al. (2012), but its concentration would be much lower 341 than in the S-nZVI system. Nevertheless, rapid formation of BPA in the S-nZVI 342 system should be considered as an advantage over the NS-nZVI system since BPA is 343 less toxic and readily degradable than brominated BPA (McCormick et al., 2010; 344 Chang et al., 2012; Yang and Chan, 2015). On the basis of the transformation products 345 identified in this study, the transformation pathways of TBBPA in the S-nZVI and 346 NS-nZVI systems were proposed (Text S3 and Fig. S4). In brief, TBBPA may 347 undergo a sequential debromination pathway to form less brominated products or 348 even non-brominated product. During each step, only one bromine atom was likely 349 replaced by a hydrogen atom. Indeed, similar pathways have also been proposed 350 previously for the transformation of TBBPA by other iron-based nanoparticles such as 351 nZVI, Ag/Fe, Ni/Fe and Fe/SiO2 (Luo et al., 2010; Lin et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2012; 352 Li et al., 2016a). 353

3.3 Kinetics of TBBPA transformation by S-nZVI and NS-nZVI 354 The time-dependent TBBPA concentration profile over 24-hour in the NS-nZVI 355 system could be adequately fit to a three-parameter single exponential decay model 356 proposed by Lin et al. (2012) (Text S4 and Fig. S5). By contrast, the TBBPA 357 concentration profile measured for the S-nZVI system could be well described by a 358 four-step sequential pseudo-first-order rate model (Text S5 and Fig. S6). This 359 discrepancy in the rates of TBBPA transformation between the NS-nZVI and S-nZVI 360 system may be due to the formation of FeS on the nZVI surface. Lin et al. (2012) 361 have reported that FeS could efficiently inhibit iron oxidation and corrosion of the 362 nZVI, which could otherwise have led to a gradual loss of the reactive sites on nZVI 363 for TBBPA as the reaction proceeded.
